has been made at home and abroad that next
year will greatly aid the organization.
A glance at the personnel of the clubs is of
interest. Thirty-six men compose the organization, of these, eighteen, or one-half, are
graduate or medical students; and, of the undergraduates, nine, or one-half, are Freshmen.
A strong undergraduate neucleus is thus assured for next year. There should be, however, a much larger proportion of college
members; and '02 and '03 men are urged to
spend their leisure moments during the coming summer in practicing on some instrument
in order to swell the members of the clubs next
fall and help to repair losses.
The difficulty of obtaining suitable men for
the clubs would disappear, however, if it were
more widely realized that their members participate in some very great benefits, Indeed
one can hardly describe too feelingly the advantages and pleasures enjoyed on the concerts
and excursions, and especially on the Easter
trips. The men are still thinking, with sighs
of regret, of the sailing parties around Hampden Roads, the picturesque Fort, the dances
at the Chamberlin, the "sing-songs" on the
boat, and the occasional little "rough-houses."
These, and such as these, caniiot fail to be
among the most happy memories of all Hopkins men who were on the musical clubs of
1901.

NEW UNIVERSITY SONGS.
strange to many people outside
IT ofhastheseemed
University that the Hopkins has so
few college songs. Some persons have even
hinted that the reason for this was a lack of
true college spirit. This explanation however
is most decidedly erroneous, for to those who
have looked into the matter at all, it is evident
that the true reason could more surely be found
in the fact that never before has the attention
of the student body been drawn to the subject
of college songs.
To this end the musical organizations have
determined to open a prize competition for the
best words, set either to original or popular
music. Of course if a song with original words
and musicis handed in,it will be given preference
to verses alone—yet if the words are set to

some air which can be used in the Glee Club
or on the athletic grounds, provided neither
"Dixie" nor "Georgia" is used, it will stand
nearly as good a chance of taking a prize as
the song with original music.
These prizes have been offered; the first of
Sio.00, the second of $5.00, and the third of
$3.00. The Judges will be Dr. Herbert E.
Green and Messrs. E. L. Turnbull, J. A. E.
Eyster, E. Smith and H. Eager. The prizes
will be decided by the vote of these men.
It is hoped that every man at present in the
University and those formerly connected with
it will take part in this contest, either from a
desire to win a prize, or from his love for his
Alma Mater, or—better yet—from a happy
combination of both these incentives.
As the prizes will be awarded on the 3oth of
June it is necessary for those who expect to
compete to hand in their work not later than
this date.
W W

THE NEWS-LETTER.
PROFESSOR ROWLAND.
1848-1901.

of all the teaching bodies of
A MEETING
the University, philosophical and medical,
was held in the Donovan Room on Saturday
afternoon, April 27. After remarks by President Gilman, Professor Ames (read by Dr.
Bliss), Professor Reid, Professor Remsen and
Dr. Welch, the following minute, presented by
a committee consisting of Professors Gildersleeve and Remsen, was unanimously adopted:
We, the Faculty of the Johns Hopkins University, assembled to do honor to the memory
of our late colleague, Professor Rowland, herewith record our appreciation of his genius and
his services, and our sorrow for his untimely
death.
In losing Henry Augustus Rowland we have
lost a great light, a great force, a great example. His fame abides and will ever be a precious possession of the University, inseparably
connected as it is with the foundation and the
growth of the institution, but in the withdrawal of a unique personality and the sudden
close of a career of high performance and, if
possible, still higher promise, our collective
life has suffered a loss which is as incalculable
as genius itself. Rowland's eminence as a
physicist is indisputable. There is no danger
of an overestimate. The only danger is that
we who stood so near him have not taken the
full measure of the man as. he will appear to
after times. Of his manner of work those only
who were closely associated with him have a
right to speak, and yet even they could only
divine the swift processes of his intellect, his
marvellous intuitions, and admire with the
rest of the world his penetrating vision, his unfailing directness in the quest of truth. In
every problem he sought the ultimate principle, and the moral lesson of his scientific life is
not less impressive to those who were not engaged in his special line of work than it is to
those who followed him as pupils follow a
master, as fellow workers follow a gifted
leader. This directness, this honesty, characterized him throughout. He was a man of
one piece. There was no affectation in his

3

manner of living, no sham interest in that
which lay outside of his field of work or his
personal sympathy. He felt the responsibility
of his gifts, the importance of his message,
and those who came within the range of his
infldence owe as much to his singleness of
purpose as to the illumination of his intellect.
Yet, in paying our tribute to Rowland's high
intellectual and moral endowments, we must
not overlook the human side of this rare man.
In all the intimate relations of life, his fidelity,
his devotion and his generosity matched his
exalted scientific standard, and those who
called him friend, and those who shared the
hours of relaxation which lessened the strain
of his intense work, will carry with them to
the end an affectionate remembrance of the
great physicist whose work for the University,
for the country, and for the world the annals
of scientific research and invention will not
suffer to be forgotten.
Resolved, That this minute be transmitted to
the Trustees with the request that it form a
part of their permanent record, and that a copy
be communicated by them to Mrs. Rowland
and to the family of our late colleague.

the eve of our last issue the University
ON experienced
the severest loss suffered in
the twenty-five years of its existence. The
whole scientific world mourns with us the loss
of Dr. Rowland, Professor of Physics, whose
remarkable discoveries and inventions have
made him America's greatest physicist.
His death, coming as it did ere he was able
to give to science his latest creation will
indefinitely retard the completion :of this
invention, for he alone possessed the secret of
its complex mechanism.
The fame of his achievements redoun do the
honor of Johns Hopkins, but their benefits,
not limited by such narrow confines, accrue
to the world.
The loss of such a one is irreparable; truly,
as our President said—''A great man has fallen
in the ranks."
W W

Musical Clubs have terminated another
THE
successful season, and added fresh laurels to
those won in former years. Hopkins can produce at least two things to perfection—lacrosse
players, and musicians, and this year's output
of both has fully realized all expectations.
The Hopkins Mandolin Club has been pronounced by unbiased hearers the best among
the colleges. So we have reason to be proud.

congratulating the Lacrosse team on its
IN recent
great victory over the Crescents,—
the only team that beat Hopkins last year and
a team that for years has not been beaten by
a college twelve, we feel double gladness. A
victory over the Crescent Athletic Club at any
time, by any college team, would be a subject
for congratulation; but when we consider the
conditions surrounding this year's contest,
even greater credit is due to the men on the
team and to the coaches. When Hopkins
lined up, their opponents only recognized three
men. There were in the line-up five men who
made the team this year, and who had played
in only one college game,—and only one man
who had been playing Lacrosse for more
than two years.
Another fact to be remembered is that every
member of the team is an undergraduate student, and not a man knew how to play Lacrosse
before he was connected with the University.
All these facts point to the victory as a result
of hard training, and most conscientious efforts
on the part of the men; and it is for their endeavors to keep the Lacrosse standard of
Hopkins up to the championship level that
we desire to thank and congratulate everybody
connected with the team.
In connection with this subject, it is most
desirable that as large a crowd of rooters as
possible accompany the team to Swarthmore
on May I all. The game with Swarthmore
College is the only game we have away from
home this year, and a great deal depends on
this contest whether we will hold the title of
"Champions of the United States" for the
year 1901. We have defeated the Crescents;
we want to defeat all the colleges. Therefore
every student who is able should show his appreciation of the team's work and help them
to win by going along to Swarthmore.

rious career of past nines at this University it
is not to be wondered at that the Board paused
long to consider the advisability of embarking
upon any such hazardous undertaking. Its
final course, however, affords an opportunity
for our base-ball enthusiasts to show that they
are really in earnest, and to atone, to some extent, at least, for the follies of bygone days.
Hopkins is certainly large enough to possess a
base-ball nine, and the NEWS LETTER believes,
just as firmly as it believed last year, that with
proper work and discipline the University
should put on the field a team worthy of the
Black and Blue. Whether or not this will be
the case remains with the players and their
captain to decide. To be sure, the latter can
not do all, but he is largely responsible for the
success or failure of the team. Now it is for
the base-ballists to decide whether or not the
National Game is to be included in our list of
sports, for it is certain that if this year's team
pursues a policy similar to that pursued by
last year's the Athletic Board will ponder long
and deeply before again sanctioning the same.

In the course of my reading, I recently
came upon a definition of what a perfect education is, in the essay by Mr. Frederick Harrison on the "Voice of Crooks." As I recall it,
the passage ran somewhat like this: a scheme
of education, to be symmetrical and well-balanced, should give equal attention to the development of the three great intellectual faculties, reflection, memory, and imagination. In
pondering over this statement, I have naturally
considered whether or not, the college courses
in this country coincide with the idea of Mr.
Harrison, and although I have not the advantages of higher education afforded an editor on
the NEWS-LETTER staff, I still venture to express on so vital a matter. It seems to me
that the imagination is neglected in our colleges.
To be sure, the quality of reflection is developed thoroughly. It takes the most careful
reasoning to see the practical object of a modern course in math-saturated physics. Great
consideration is required in order always to be
ready for the ten-minute bell. As a stimulus

to most profound meditation, nothing can
equal the post-mortem effect of an exam. To
grasp the significance of a rule of rhetoric, to
appreciate the beauty of an unprepared poem
in a foreign language, to comprehend the
awful majesty of a mathematical formula, all
this exercises the reflective power to the point
of exhaustion.
The memory is also trained. To keep a
fresh supply of excuses for cuts and lateness
is a continual tax on the memory. To remember the amount of apparatus demolished in
chemical lab, is a herculean task. To remember the various shady jokes perpetrated by the
profs.; to recall the fact that the instructor is
instructing; to remember a lesson that you
never prepared; to remember to pay the bills
from the authorities are all severe tests; but
the crowning test of all is to remember the
money you owe your classmates.
• But with all the care that is bestowed upon
the faculties of reflection and memory, imagination is entirely neglected in the course of
studies. I protest that college is a dry matter
of fact; and by thus calling attention to the
defect, I hope to enlist the influence of the
editors of the NEWS-LETTER to remedy the

"Resolved—that in the withdrawal of Mr.
William H. Maddren from active participation
in Johns Hopkins Athletics, we are conscious
of a great loss."
Mr. Maddren found Hopkins Athletics in a
stagnant condition, with weak teams, and lack
of interest. He first built up the Lacrosse
Team, and the fame of Hopkins Lacrosse in
the last four years is primarily due to him.
He then remodeled the Athletic Association,
endeavoring to make it a strong body which
should govern athletics, secure harmony between teams, and exact vigorous training and
team work. We recognize that whatever
success has been attained in this direction is
largely due to his efforts during the past five
years.
"Resolved, That this expression of our regard for Mr. William M. Maddren and of our
regret at his resignation of the office of President of this association, be suitably engrossed
and presented to him."

THE NEWS-LETTER.

game was a splendid exhibition of lacrosse,
notwithstanding the severe rain storm which
took place. The field was very wet before the
teams ventured upon it,.but that did not deter
the Hopkins men from getting in the prettiest
passing they have done this year. Captain
De Casenova, of the Crescents, said after the
game that the attack work was the best and
cleanest he had ever seen.
There were few excuses made by the Crescents over their defeat, and it was the general
expression of opinion that they would rather
lose to Hopkins than to anybody else. It is
interesting to note that before the game several
men now or formerly connected with the
Crescents said that they hoped we would
"shake them up." But the shaking up came
in rather a "jarring" way.
The team work of Hopkins and particularly
the body checking, which the coaches remarked after the University of Pennsylvania
game as being lamentably weak, showed out
strongly. The play was like clock work, and
there were few misplays by our men. Yet all
this time the Crescents put up a creditable
game. Their play was much better and faster
than that of the University of Pennsylvania,
and when this fact is borne in mind one can
realize that Hopkins had improved in a wonderful manner inside of one week.
The first half furnished much excitement
for the substitutes and friends of both teams
who watched the game from the grandstand.
From the face-off Hopkins showed uniformly
better stick work than the Crescents, and after
the ball had been carried up and down the field
by each team, Bandel got it. After splendid
passing and team work by Bandel, Putts and
Hatch, the ball was passed to Putts, who shot
the first goal. After this the Crescents braced
up considerably, spurred on by the exhortations of their leaders, and our defense men
were kept busy keeping the Crescent attack
away from goal. At the end of the first half
the ball was in Crescent territory, the Brooklynites having failed to score.
The Crescents did better in the second half,
but so did Hopkins, and the team work of the
latter was like mechanism. The former had

the ball close to our goal on several occasions,
but without success. Goal-keeper Doyle, of
the Crescents, stopped some pretty shots made
by our team. His defense men were constantly
drawn out by Putts and Bernheim, and Hopkins kept uncovering just at the right time,
but failed to shoot a goal. Before the Black
and Blue got its second tally, Starr got possession of the ball and, after carrying it down
past our defense, passed to Cruse, who tried a
long shot which got by Ranft. This was
Crescents' only goal. Hopkins scored twice
after this. P. Bernheim got the ball and passed
to Hatch, who made one of the most sensational plays of the game by carrying the ball
down the field unaided, placing it in the net.
Hatch followed this up a little later, on a pass
from Bernheim, by another goal.

C. C N.Y., 1.

The boys won their fourth successive victory
on Saturday last by defeating the fast team
from the City College of New York by a score
of 7 to r at Electric Park. The day was beautiful, but, owing to the distance from town,
the size of the crowd was rather disheartening
to the management, because of the heavy expenses they were under. On account of the

THE NEWS-LETTER.
recent heavy rains the grounds were in poor
condition, and the long grass often hid the
ball from the players.
From the first it was clearly seen that the
visitors were easily outclassed, and little opportunity was afforded for team work till the
second half, when C. C. N. Y. took a brace
and for a time gaVe a pretty exhibition of
passing and body checking. Several times did
they succeed in upsetting the home boys, but
their brace came too late; the game had been
won in the first half.
After the face-off, Tough got the ball and
passed it to Abercrombie, who raced up the
field to the net after having successfully attempted a goal. A repetition of the first performance was the result of the second face-off.
After some pretty tipping by the Hopkins
men, Putts got the ball and shot the second
goal after a few minutes of play. Within a
short time Putts again shot a goal.
It was only after three goals had been shot
that the New Yorkers succeeded in getting the
ball. Their defense got the ball past Abercrombie, and the attack carried it well up toward the goal. By clever work Straus broke
up the play of the visitors, and together with
Tyler, Bruton and Schmeisser, succeeded in
getting the ball back to our attack. Before
the half closed, B. Bentheim and Hatch got in
two more scores.
In the second half the C. C. N. Y. men had
warmed up sufficiently to make it interesting
for our men, who realized that they were not
going to have a "soft snap" this time. The
body checking of the visitors now proved
effectual, and often the wearers of the Black
and Blue were rolling on the green sward.
For a time the New Yorkers kept the ball well
up in their attack and often shot for goal, but
with no success till Solow made a desperate
try, and his attempt was rewarded by the one
tally made by the visitors. Putts succeeded
in shooting another goal, and before the half
was over Bernheim had shot his second goal.

HOPKINS WINS AT PENNSYLVANIA.
N Saturday the Hopkins relay team won
their race at the great carnival of relay
races at the University of Pennsylvania. Those
who went as members of the team were: Wm.
E. Hoffman, Jr., captain; Joseph T. England,
H. S. Whitman, T. F. Riggs; and William
Thatcher, substitute.
In the shotput and discus throw Garrett
won third place.
The results are as follows:
Shotput (special)—Won by R. Sheldon,
Yale; second, F. E. Beck, Yale; third, R.
Garrett, Johns Hopkins. Best put, 43 feet 2
inches.
Distance Throw (special)—Won by R. Sheldon, Yale; second, A. DeWitt, Princeton;
third, R. Garrett, Johns Hopkins; fourth, T.
T. Hare, Pennsylvania. Best throw, 113 feet
inches.
Intercollegiate relay, won by Johns Hopkins University; second, Gallaudet College;
third, Western Maryland College; fourth, St.
Johns College; fifth, University of Maryland.
Time, 3.42 4-5.

NEW UNIVERSITY SONGS.
strange to many people outside
IT ofhastheseemed
University that the Hopkins has so
few college songs. Some persons have even
hinted that the reason for this was a lack of
true college spirit. This explanation however
is most decidedly erroneous, for to those who
have looked into the matter at all, it is evident
that the true reason could more surely be found
in the fact that never before has the attention
of the student body been drawn to the subject
of college songs.
To this end the musical organizations have
determined to open a prize competition for the
best words, set either to original or popular
music. Of course if a song with original words
and musicis handed in,it will be given preference
to verses alone—yet if the words are set to

some air which can be used in the Glee Club
or on the athletic grounds, provided neither
"Dixie" nor "Georgia" is used, it will stand
nearly as good a chance of taking a prize as
the song with original music.
These prizes have been offered; the first of
Sio.00, the second of $5.00, and the third of
$3.00. The Judges will be Dr. Herbert E.
Green and Messrs. E. L. Turnbull, J. A. E.
Eyster, E. Smith and H. Eager. The prizes
will be decided by the vote of these men.
It is hoped that every man at present in the
University and those formerly connected with
it will take part in this contest, either from a
desire to win a prize, or from his love for his
Alma Mater, or—better yet—from a happy
combination of both these incentives.
As the prizes will be awarded on the 3oth of
June it is necessary for those who expect to
compete to hand in their work not later than
this date.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
PROFESSOR ROWLAND.
1848-1901.

of all the teaching bodies of
A MEETING
the University, philosophical and medical,
was held in the Donovan Room on Saturday
afternoon, April 27. After remarks by President Gilman, Professor Ames (read by Dr.
Bliss), Professor Reid, Professor Remsen and
Dr. Welch, the following minute, presented by
a committee consisting of Professors Gildersleeve and Remsen, was unanimously adopted:
We, the Faculty of the Johns Hopkins University, assembled to do honor to the memory
of our late colleague, Professor Rowland, herewith record our appreciation of his genius and
his services, and our sorrow for his untimely
death.
In losing Henry Augustus Rowland we have
lost a great light, a great force, a great example. His fame abides and will ever be a precious possession of the University, inseparably
connected as it is with the foundation and the
growth of the institution, but in the withdrawal of a unique personality and the sudden
close of a career of high performance and, if
possible, still higher promise, our collective
life has suffered a loss which is as incalculable
as genius itself. Rowland's eminence as a
physicist is indisputable. There is no danger
of an overestimate. The only danger is that
we who stood so near him have not taken the
full measure of the man as. he will appear to
after times. Of his manner of work those only
who were closely associated with him have a
right to speak, and yet even they could only
divine the swift processes of his intellect, his
marvellous intuitions, and admire with the
rest of the world his penetrating vision, his unfailing directness in the quest of truth. In
every problem he sought the ultimate principle, and the moral lesson of his scientific life is
not less impressive to those who were not engaged in his special line of work than it is to
those who followed him as pupils follow a
master, as fellow workers follow a gifted
leader. This directness, this honesty, characterized him throughout. He was a man of
one piece. There was no affectation in his

3

manner of living, no sham interest in that
which lay outside of his field of work or his
personal sympathy. He felt the responsibility
of his gifts, the importance of his message,
and those who came within the range of his
infldence owe as much to his singleness of
purpose as to the illumination of his intellect.
Yet, in paying our tribute to Rowland's high
intellectual and moral endowments, we must
not overlook the human side of this rare man.
In all the intimate relations of life, his fidelity,
his devotion and his generosity matched his
exalted scientific standard, and those who
called him friend, and those who shared the
hours of relaxation which lessened the strain
of his intense work, will carry with them to
the end an affectionate remembrance of the
great physicist whose work for the University,
for the country, and for the world the annals
of scientific research and invention will not
suffer to be forgotten.
Resolved, That this minute be transmitted to
the Trustees with the request that it form a
part of their permanent record, and that a copy
be communicated by them to Mrs. Rowland
and to the family of our late colleague.
ww

the eve of our last issue the University
ON experienced
the severest loss suffered in
the twenty-five years of its existence. The
whole scientific world mourns with us the loss
of Dr. Rowland, Professor of Physics, whose
remarkable discoveries and inventions have
made him America's greatest physicist.
His death, coming as it did ere he was able
to give to science his latest creation will
indefinitely retard the completion :of this
invention, for he alone possessed the secret of
its complex mechanism.
The fame of his achievements redoun do the
honor of Johns Hopkins, but their benefits,
not limited by such narrow confines, accrue
to the world.
The loss of such a one is irreparable; truly,
as our President said—''A great man has fallen
in the ranks."
W W

Musical Clubs have terminated another
THE
successful season, and added fresh laurels to
those won in former years. Hopkins can produce at least two things to perfection—lacrosse
players, and musicians, and this year's output
of both has fully realized all expectations.
The Hopkins Mandolin Club has been pronounced by unbiased hearers the best among
the colleges. So we have reason to be proud.

congratulating the Lacrosse team on its
IN recent
great victory over the Crescents,—
the only team that beat Hopkins last year and
a team that for years has not been beaten by
a college twelve, we feel double gladness. A
victory over the Crescent Athletic Club at any
time, by any college team, would be a subject
for congratulation; but when we consider the
conditions surrounding this year's contest,
even greater credit is due to the men on the
team and to the coaches. When Hopkins
lined up, their opponents only recognized three
men. There were in the line-up five men who
made the team this year, and who had played
in only one college game,—and only one man
who had been playing Lacrosse for more
than two years.
Another fact to be remembered is that every
member of the team is an undergraduate student, and not a man knew how to play Lacrosse
before he was connected with the University.
All these facts point to the victory as a result
of hard training, and most conscientious efforts
on the part of the men; and it is for their endeavors to keep the Lacrosse standard of
Hopkins up to the championship level that
we desire to thank and congratulate everybody
connected with the team.
In connection with this subject, it is most
desirable that as large a crowd of rooters as
possible accompany the team to Swarthmore
on May I all. The game with Swarthmore
College is the only game we have away from
home this year, and a great deal depends on
this contest whether we will hold the title of
"Champions of the United States" for the
year 1901. We have defeated the Crescents;
we want to defeat all the colleges. Therefore
every student who is able should show his appreciation of the team's work and help them
to win by going along to Swarthmore.

In the course of my reading, I recently
came upon a definition of what a perfect education is, in the essay by Mr. Frederick Harrison on the "Voice of Crooks." As I recall it,
the passage ran somewhat like this: a scheme
of education, to be symmetrical and well-balanced, should give equal attention to the development of the three great intellectual faculties, reflection, memory, and imagination. In
pondering over this statement, I have naturally
considered whether or not, the college courses
in this country coincide with the idea of Mr.
Harrison, and although I have not the advantages of higher education afforded an editor on
the NEWS-LETTER staff, I still venture to express on so vital a matter. It seems to me
that the imagination is neglected in our colleges.

reasoning to see the practical object of a modern course in math-saturated physics. Great
consideration is required in order always to be
ready for the ten-minute bell. As a stimulus

to most profound meditation, nothing can
equal the post-mortem effect of an exam. To
grasp the significance of a rule of rhetoric, to
appreciate the beauty of an unprepared poem
in a foreign language, to comprehend the
awful majesty of a mathematical formula, all
this exercises the reflective power to the point
of exhaustion.
The memory is also trained. To keep a
fresh supply of excuses for cuts and lateness
is a continual tax on the memory. To remember the amount of apparatus demolished in
chemical lab, is a herculean task. To remember the various shady jokes perpetrated by the
profs.; to recall the fact that the instructor is
instructing; to remember a lesson that you
never prepared; to remember to pay the bills
from the authorities are all severe tests; but
the crowning test of all is to remember the
money you owe your classmates.
• But with all the care that is bestowed upon
the faculties of reflection and memory, imagination is entirely neglected in the course of
studies. I protest that college is a dry matter
of fact; and by thus calling attention to the
defect, I hope to enlist the influence of the
editors of the NEWS-LETTER to remedy the

"Resolved—that in the withdrawal of Mr.
William H. Maddren from active participation
in Johns Hopkins Athletics, we are conscious
of a great loss."
Mr. Maddren found Hopkins Athletics in a
stagnant condition, with weak teams, and lack
of interest. He first built up the Lacrosse
Team, and the fame of Hopkins Lacrosse in
the last four years is primarily due to him.
He then remodeled the Athletic Association,
endeavoring to make it a strong body which
should govern athletics, secure harmony between teams, and exact vigorous training and
team work. We recognize that whatever
success has been attained in this direction is
largely due to his efforts during the past five
years.
"Resolved, That this expression of our regard for Mr. William M. Maddren and of our
regret at his resignation of the office of President of this association, be suitably engrossed
and presented to him."

THE NEWS-LETTER.

game was a splendid exhibition of lacrosse,
notwithstanding the severe rain storm which
took place. The field was very wet before the
teams ventured upon it,.but that did not deter
the Hopkins men from getting in the prettiest
passing they have done this year. Captain
De Casenova, of the Crescents, said after the
game that the attack work was the best and
cleanest he had ever seen.
There were few excuses made by the Crescents over their defeat, and it was the general
expression of opinion that they would rather
lose to Hopkins than to anybody else. It is
interesting to note that before the game several
men now or formerly connected with the
Crescents said that they hoped we would
"shake them up." But the shaking up came
in rather a "jarring" way.
The team work of Hopkins and particularly
the body checking, which the coaches remarked after the University of Pennsylvania
game as being lamentably weak, showed out
strongly. The play was like clock work, and
there were few misplays by our men. Yet all
this time the Crescents put up a creditable
game. Their play was much better and faster
than that of the University of Pennsylvania,
and when this fact is borne in mind one can
realize that Hopkins had improved in a wonderful manner inside of one week.
The first half furnished much excitement
for the substitutes and friends of both teams
who watched the game from the grandstand.
From the face-off Hopkins showed uniformly
better stick work than the Crescents, and after
the ball had been carried up and down the field
by each team, Bandel got it. After splendid
passing and team work by Bandel, Putts and
Hatch, the ball was passed to Putts, who shot
the first goal. After this the Crescents braced
up considerably, spurred on by the exhortations of their leaders, and our defense men
were kept busy keeping the Crescent attack
away from goal. At the end of the first half
the ball was in Crescent territory, the Brooklynites having failed to score.
The Crescents did better in the second half,
but so did Hopkins, and the team work of the
latter was like mechanism. The former had

the ball close to our goal on several occasions,
but without success. Goal-keeper Doyle, of
the Crescents, stopped some pretty shots made
by our team. His defense men were constantly
drawn out by Putts and Bernheim, and Hopkins kept uncovering just at the right time,
but failed to shoot a goal. Before the Black
and Blue got its second tally, Starr got possession of the ball and, after carrying it down
past our defense, passed to Cruse, who tried a
long shot which got by Ranft. This was
Crescents' only goal. Hopkins scored twice
after this. P. Bernheim got the ball and passed
to Hatch, who made one of the most sensational plays of the game by carrying the ball
down the field unaided, placing it in the net.
Hatch followed this up a little later, on a pass
from Bernheim, by another goal.

C. C N.Y., 1.

The boys won their fourth successive victory
on Saturday last by defeating the fast team
from the City College of New York by a score
of 7 to r at Electric Park. The day was beautiful, but, owing to the distance from town,
the size of the crowd was rather disheartening
to the management, because of the heavy expenses they were under. On account of the

THE NEWS-LETTER.
recent heavy rains the grounds were in poor
condition, and the long grass often hid the
ball from the players.
From the first it was clearly seen that the
visitors were easily outclassed, and little opportunity was afforded for team work till the
second half, when C. C. N. Y. took a brace
and for a time gaVe a pretty exhibition of
passing and body checking. Several times did
they succeed in upsetting the home boys, but
their brace came too late; the game had been
won in the first half.
After the face-off, Tough got the ball and
passed it to Abercrombie, who raced up the
field to the net after having successfully attempted a goal. A repetition of the first performance was the result of the second face-off.
After some pretty tipping by the Hopkins
men, Putts got the ball and shot the second
goal after a few minutes of play. Within a
short time Putts again shot a goal.
It was only after three goals had been shot
that the New Yorkers succeeded in getting the
ball. Their defense got the ball past Abercrombie, and the attack carried it well up toward the goal. By clever work Straus broke
up the play of the visitors, and together with
Tyler, Bruton and Schmeisser, succeeded in
getting the ball back to our attack. Before
the half closed, B. Bentheim and Hatch got in
two more scores.
In the second half the C. C. N. Y. men had
warmed up sufficiently to make it interesting
for our men, who realized that they were not
going to have a "soft snap" this time. The
body checking of the visitors now proved
effectual, and often the wearers of the Black
and Blue were rolling on the green sward.
For a time the New Yorkers kept the ball well
up in their attack and often shot for goal, but
with no success till Solow made a desperate
try, and his attempt was rewarded by the one
tally made by the visitors. Putts succeeded
in shooting another goal, and before the half
was over Bernheim had shot his second goal.

N Saturday the Hopkins relay team won
their race at the great carnival of relay
races at the University of Pennsylvania. Those
who went as members of the team were: Wm.
E. Hoffman, Jr., captain; Joseph T. England,
H. S. Whitman, T. F. Riggs; and William
Thatcher, substitute.
In the shotput and discus throw Garrett
won third place.

Garrett, Johns Hopkins. Best put, 43 feet 2
inches.
Distance Throw (special)—Won by R. Sheldon, Yale; second, A. DeWitt, Princeton;
third, R. Garrett, Johns Hopkins; fourth, T.
T. Hare, Pennsylvania. Best throw, 113 feet
inches.

Johns College; fifth, University of Maryland.

November 7th, Noo.
While visiting the Paris Exposition of 1900, the wonderful display of
wines from all parts of the world was made a special study by our representative, who secured some very line cuvees of French wines, both
red and white, such as Chateau l'ontet Canet, Chateau Larose, Chateau Lafitte, Chattau Margaux, Clarets; Sauternes, Haut Sauternes,
and Chateau Coutet. The latter finer than Chateau Yquem and not so
sweet. Also some special vintag.s of Deinhard & Co.'s celebrated Rhine
Wines selected while visiting their great wine vaults at Coblenz on the
Rhine. The most valuable selection of all was the prize Oporto Port,
the finest of all Offiey Forrester & Co.'s exhibit; a very old, strictly
pure, rich, medicinal Port wine, which will be shipped in 120 gallon
pipes direct from the Exposition ground to
